meanings.definition: Skankers (noun): A person who engages in promiscuous or immoral behavior.
meanings.sent1: Sheila was known as one of the local skankers for her wild parties.
meanings.sent2: The tabloids often portray celebrities as skankers for their scandalous relationships.
meanings.sent3: At the costume party, everyone jokingly called Bob a skankers for his outrageous outfit.
meanings.sent4: The gossip magazine labeled the actress as a skankers, stirring up controversy.
meanings.sent5: In the school play, the character of the skankers was played with exaggerated flair.

meanings.definition: Skankers (verb): To dance in a lewd or provocative manner.
meanings.sent1: During the dance competition, she decided to skankers to impress the judges.
meanings.sent2: At the club, the dancers started to skankers when the DJ played a catchy tune.
meanings.sent3: The wedding guests were surprised when the elderly couple began to skankers on the dance floor.
meanings.sent4: The music video featured dancers skankers in neon lights, creating a mesmerizing effect.
meanings.sent5: In the movie, the protagonist learned to skankers to win the heart of their love interest.

meanings.definition: Skankers (adjective): Describing something or someone as dirty, unkempt, or unpleasant.
meanings.sent1: The abandoned house had a skankers smell that made everyone hold their noses.
meanings.sent2: The alley behind the restaurant was filled with skankers garbage bags waiting to be collected.
meanings.sent3: The old rug in the living room looked skankers after years of wear and tear.
meanings.sent4: The pond water turned a skankers green color due to pollution in the area.
meanings.sent5: The cafeteria served a skankers meal that no one wanted to eat.
